THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Gloria Cole and George DeWalt, Jr., in their capacities as Personal Representatives of the Estate of George Ernest Cole, deceased,
Petitioners/Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
South Carolina Electric & Gas, Inc., Respondent/Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO
THE COURT OF APPEALS 

Appeal from Richland County
Alison Renee Lee, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25932
Heard December 1, 2004 - Filed January 31, 2005

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
F. Xavier Starkes and William T. Toal, of Johnson, Toal & Battiste, P.A., of Columbia, for petitioners/respondents.
Robert A. McKenzie and Gary H. Johnson, II, of McDonald, McKenzie, Rubin, Miller & Lybrand, L.L.P., of Columbia, for respondent/petitioner.
      
    
  


ACTING CHIEF JUSTICE MOORE:Â  We granted a writ of certiorari to review the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision involving application of the Recreational Use Statute, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 27-3-10 et seq. (1991), and assumption of the risk.[1]Â  We affirm as modified.
FACTS
Petitioners/respondents (hereinafter collectively referred to as â€œColeâ€) brought this wrongful death action for the death of their son George Cole.Â  George drowned on August 6, 1997, at the age of fourteen while swimming at a Lake Murray recreation site owned by respondent/petitioner South Carolina Electric & Gas (SCE&G).Â  Cole alleged SCE&G was negligent and grossly negligent for failing to provide lifeguards, life-saving equipment, and the proper warnings at the site.Â  On SCE&Gâ€™s motion for summary judgment, the trial court found SCE&G was entitled to immunity from liability for simple negligence under the Recreational Use Statute and the trial proceeded only on the issue of SCE&Gâ€™s gross negligence.
At trial, Cole produced evidence that George was at Lake Murray Site #1 with his friend Vincent, Vincentâ€™s mother, and her boyfriend.Â  By all accounts, George was a good swimmer.Â  The boys were told not to go into the water without telling the adults but they did not follow this directive.Â  Vincent testified that he and George swam out to the safety line, or buoy line.Â  They did not know the water at the buoy line was over their heads.Â  The two boys were racing back to shore when Vincent turned around and saw George floundering.Â  Vincent ran for a security guard who called 911.Â  
Another witness saw George crying for help and bobbing up and down.Â  Several bystanders attempted a rescue but could not find George under the water.Â  After about fifteen to twenty minutes, his body was found in seven or eight feet of water at the bottom of the lake.Â  He could not be revived.
At trial, Coleâ€™s aquatic safety expert, Stanly Shulman, testified that George would have lived had there been a lifeguard on duty because lifeguards are trained to search under water.Â  Further, bystanders could have saved him had there been safety equipment available.Â  Shulman also testified that the buoy line should have been placed at a depth of three-and-a-half to five feet, rather than seven to eight feet, and that depth markers should have been placed.Â  The signs warning simply â€œno lifeguard on dutyâ€ were inadequate in his opinion to warn of the dangers inherent in swimming in a lake.Â  Shulman also testified that SCE&G failed to develop an effective risk management plan even after two previous drownings at the site.Â  
The jury returned a verdict for SCE&G and Cole appealed.Â  On appeal, the Court of Appeals affirmed summary judgment on the issue of immunity under the Recreational Use Statute but reversed and remanded for a new trial on the gross negligence cause of action because the trial judge failed to charge SCE&Gâ€™s burden to prove its affirmative defense of assumption of the risk.Â  Both parties petitioned this Court for a writ of certiorari.
DISCUSSION
Coleâ€™s Appeal
Application of the Recreational Use Statute
In 1968, our legislature enacted a Recreational Use Statute (RUS), codified at Â§Â§ 27-3-10 through -70, which limits the liability of a landowner under certain conditions.Â  In pertinent part, these sections provide as follows.Â  

Â§ 27-3-10. Declaration of purpose.
The purpose of this chapter is to encourage owners of land to make land and water areas available to the public for recreational purposes by limiting their liability toward persons entering thereon for such purposes.
Â§ 27-3-20. Definitions.
(c) "Recreational purpose" includes, but is not limited to, any of the following, or any combination thereof:Â  hunting, fishing, swimming, boating, camping, picnicking, hiking, pleasure driving, nature study, water skiing, summer and winter sports and viewing or enjoying historical, archaeological, scenic, or scientific sites.
 (d) "Charge" means the admission price or fee asked in return for invitation or permission to enter or go upon the land.
Â§ 27-3-40. Effect of permission to use property for recreational purposes.
Except as specifically recognized by or provided in Â§ 27-3-60, an owner of land who permits without charge any person having sought such permission to use such property for recreational purposes does not thereby:
(a) Extend any assurance that the premises are safe for any purpose.
(b) Confer upon such person the legal status of an invitee or licensee to whom a duty of care is owed.
(c) Assume responsibility for or incur liability for any injury to person or property caused by an act of omission of such persons.
Â§ 27-3-60. Certain liability not limited.
Nothing in this chapter limits in any way any liability which otherwise exists:
(a) For grossly negligent, willful or malicious failure to guard or warn against a dangerous condition, use, structure, or activity.
(b) For injury suffered in any case where the owner of land charges persons who enter or go on the land for the recreational use thereof. . . .

(emphasis added).
It is undisputed that on the day George drowned, the driver of the car in which George was a passenger paid a three-dollar parking fee at SCE&Gâ€™s recreational site on Lake Murray.Â  The fee is a per-vehicle charge and is not related to the number of visitors in the vehicle.Â  People who enter on foot or by bicycle are charged no fee.Â  The trial court ruled that the parking fee was not a â€œchargeâ€ within the meaning of the RUS and therefore SCE&G was entitled to the protection of the RUS.Â  
Cole contends the parking fee is a â€œchargeâ€ that fits within the exception to landowner immunity stated in Â§ 27-3-60(b).Â  However, subsection (d) specifically defines â€œchargeâ€ as â€œthe admission price or fee asked in return for invitation or permission to enter or go upon the land.â€Â  (emphasis added.)Â  This definition limits a â€œchargeâ€ to a general charge for admission to the property.Â  Courts interpreting this phrase have consistently held that a parking fee does not qualify as a â€œchargeâ€ because not everyone must pay it for admission to the property.Â  See Stone Mountain Mem. Assoc. v. Herrington, 171 S.E.2d 521 (Ga. 1969); City of Louisville v. Silcox, 977 S.W.2d 254 (Ky. App. 1998); Hanley v. State, 837 A.2d 707 (R.I. 2003); see generally Moss v. Depâ€™t of Nat. Resources, 404 N.E.2d 742 (Ohio 1980) (admission fee is a charge necessary to utilize the overall benefits of a recreational area).Â  We concur in this view and conclude a parking fee does not fit within the statutory definition of â€œcharge.â€Â  The trial court therefore properly held SCE&G is entitled to immunity for simple negligence under the RUS.
SCE&Gâ€™s Appeal
1.Â  Burden of proof on assumption of risk[2]
The trial judge declined to charge that SCE&G had the burden of proving its affirmative defense of assumption of the risk and instead charged generally that SCE&G had the burden of proving the plaintiffâ€™s â€œfaultâ€ for purposes of comparative negligence and that the jury should â€œconsider the defensesâ€ set forth by SCE&G.Â  The only charge specifically regarding assumption of the risk was to define it as a defense and then instruct:Â  â€œIf you find that . . .the plaintiff assumed the risk associated with this activity, then you would find for the defendant.â€Â  The Court of Appeals found this charge was inadequate to properly instruct the jury regarding SCE&Gâ€™s burden of proof and reversed on this issue.Â  SCE&G contends this was error on the following grounds.
a.Â  The charge as a whole was sufficient.
It is well-settled that assumption of the risk is an affirmative defense which the defendant bears the burden of proving.Â  Baldwin v. Piedmont Mfg. Co., 102 S.C. 402, 86 S.E. 379 (1915); see also Englert, Inc. v. Netherlands Ins. Co., 315 S.C. 300, 433 S.E.2d 871 (1993) (defendant has burden of proving affirmative defenses listed in Rule 8(c), SCRCP); Rule 8(c), SCRCP (assumption of risk is affirmative defense).
The question here is whether the charge as a whole conveyed this burden to the jury.Â  We agree with the Court of Appeals that it did not, especially in light of the instructions defining the plaintiffâ€™s burden of proof:

As the trial begins, the scales are even, but throughout the course of the trial as the testimony and the evidence comes in, the scales may tip back and forth.Â  If after all of the evidence has been presented, the scales remain even or they tip ever so slightly in favor of the defendant, then the plaintiffs would not have satisfied their burden of proof in this particular matter.

By contrast, the charge regarding SCE&Gâ€™s affirmative defense indicated only that the jury should â€œconsiderâ€ SCE&Gâ€™s defenses and if the jury found the plaintiff assumed the risk, it should find for SCE&G.Â  This charge gave the jury no standard by which to determine if SCE&G had established its defense.Â  The Court of Appeals properly found the charge inadequate.
b.Â  Primary implied assumption of the risk.
SCE&G contends there was no need to charge assumption of the risk under the doctrine of â€œprimary implied assumption of the risk.â€Â  We disagree.
Primary implied assumption of the risk arises when the plaintiff impliedly assumes risks inherent in a particular activity.Â  Davenport, 333 S.C. at 81, 508 S.E.2d at 570.Â  It is not a true affirmative defense but is another way of stating there is no duty to the plaintiff.Â  Id.Â  We disagree SCE&G owed no duty here.Â  A landowner has a duty to warn a licensee of concealed dangerous conditions or activities known to the landowner.Â  Vogt v. Murraywood Swim & Racquet Club, 357 S.C. 506, 593 S.E.2d 617 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Despite immunity under the RUS, SCE&G may still be liable for gross negligence which is the failure to exercise even slight care.Â  Clyburn v. Sumter County Sch. Dist. No. 17, 317 S.C. 50, 451 S.E.2d 885 (1994).Â  Whether SCE&G met this standard of care in warning only that there was no lifeguard is a question of fact for the jury. 
c.Â  Harmless error
SCE&G contends any error in the failure to charge the burden of proof is harmless because the jury must have concluded Cole failed to prove gross negligence.Â  SCE&G bases this assertion on the fact that the only question put to the trial court by the jurors was regarding the distinction between negligence and gross negligence.Â  This question, however, does not indicate the jury failed to consider assumption of the risk, especially since SCE&Gâ€™s case basically turned on proving that George assumed the risk of swimming in Lake Murray.Â  
d.Â  Assumption of risk as a matter of law
SCE&G contends George assumed the risk inherent in swimming in a natural body of water and since his fault was greater than 50%, the case should not be remanded for a new trial.
There are four requirements to establishing the defense of assumption of risk: (1) the plaintiff must have knowledge of the facts constituting a dangerous condition; (2) the plaintiff must know the condition is dangerous; (3) the plaintiff must appreciate the nature and extent of the danger; and (4) the plaintiff must voluntarily expose himself to the danger.Â  Davenport, 333 S.C. 79, 508 S.E.2d 569.Â  According to Coleâ€™s expert witness, the warning simply stating there was no lifeguard was insufficient notice of the danger involved.Â  There remains a factual issue whether George was sufficiently warned of the danger to have legally assumed the risk of swimming in Lake Murray. Â SCE&G has not established assumption of the risk as a matter of law.
2.Â  Effect of Regulation 61-50
At trial, Cole introduced evidence that at the time of Georgeâ€™s drowning, DHEC Regulation 61-50 required the use of lifeguards and lifesaving equipment.[3] Â SCE&G responded with evidence of a 1978 administrative ruling exempting it from this requirement.Â  In 1980, the regulation was amended.Â  The issue at trial was whether SCE&Gâ€™s exemption remained valid under the amended regulation.
Rather than decide this issue, the trial judge ruled it would be submitted to the jury as a factual issue.Â  In charging the jury, however, the trial judge charged only that evidence of a violation of a regulation is evidence of negligence.Â  Cole appealed, contending the trial judge should have decided whether the regulation applies as a matter of law.Â  SCE&G argued in response that the regulation conflicts with the RUS and therefore as a matter of law it does not apply regardless of whether the 1978 exemption remained valid.Â  Rather than resolve this issue, the Court of Appeals concluded any error was harmless because the trial judgeâ€™s charge instructed the jury to determine whether the regulation was violated, an instruction that was favorable to Cole who therefore could not show prejudice on appeal.
SCE&G contends the Court of Appeals should have addressed whether the regulation applies as a matter of law to resolve whether on remand a violation should be charged as evidence of negligence.Â  We agree and find as a matter of law the regulation does not apply.
The purpose of the RUS as stated in the statute is â€œto encourage owners of land to make land and water areas available to the public for recreational purposes.â€Â  Â§ 27-3-10.Â  Under the RUS a landownerâ€™s liability is limited to gross negligence, which is defined as the failure to exercise slight care.Â  Clyburn, supra.Â  By contrast, Regulation 61-50, as it read at the time this cause of action arose,[4] imposed â€œowner responsibilityâ€ for lifeguards and lifesaving equipment and subjected the violator to fines and imprisonment.Â  This regulation, as applied, conflicts with the RUS since a qualifying landowner under the RUS has a duty to exercise only slight care.Â  A duty to provide recreational safety features such as lifeguards and lifesaving equipment exceeds this â€œslight careâ€ standard.Â  Since a regulation cannot alter or add to a statute, Regulation 61-50 does not apply.Â  SeeÂ  McNickelâ€™s, Inc. v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Rev., 331 S.C. 629, 503 S.E.2d 723 (1998).
In sum, on remand a violation of Regulation 61-50â€™s safety provisions should not be charged as evidence of negligence since SCE&G has no duty under the RUS to exercise more than slight care.Â  
 AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED.
WALLER, BURNETT, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice James W. Johnson, Jr., concur.

[1]Cole v. South Carolina Elec. & Gas, Inc., 355 S.C. 183, 584 S.E.2d 405 (Ct. App. 2003). 
[2]Assumption of the risk is abolished for causes of action accruing after November 9, 1998.Â  Davenport v. Cotton Hope Plantation Horizontal Prop. Regime, 333 S.C. 71, 508 S.E.2d 565 (1998).Â  This cause of action arose before that date. 
[3]This regulation was subsequently amended in 1999 as discussed at footnote 4, infra. 
[4] Regulation 61-50 was amended in 1999 and now applies only to a natural swimming area if there is â€œa fee or membership required to gain access to a natural freshwater location.â€Â  Further, the regulation no longer requires safety measures such as lifeguards and life-saving equipment but applies solely to monitoring water quality.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Linda Angus, individually, and as class representative for all those similarly situated,
        Appellant/Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
The City of Myrtle Beach, Respondent/Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25934
Heard June 10, 2004 - Filed January 31, 2005

AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART; REMANDED


  
    
      
L. Sidney Connor, IV, of Kelaher, Connell & Connor, P.C., and Natale Fata, both of Surfside Beach, for appellant/respondent.
James B. Van Osdell and Charles B. Jordan, Jr., both of Van Osdell, Lester, Howe & Jordan, of Myrtle Beach, for respondent/appellant.
      
    
  


JUSTICE MOORE:Â  This action was brought by appellant/respondent Angus, a municipal taxpayer, challenging the property tax rollback millage rate adopted by respondent/appellant City of Myrtle Beach (Myrtle Beach) for the 1999-2000 fiscal year.Â  Angus appeals a final order holding that Myrtle Beach did not violate S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 6-1-320 (2004) or Â§ 12-37-251(E) (2000).Â  Myrtle Beach cross-appeals an order certifying a class of municipal taxpayers, and an order refusing to join the South Carolina Department of Revenue as a party.Â  We affirm the rulings appealed by Myrtle Beach.Â  We agree with Angus that the millage rate was improperly calculated, reverse on this issue, and remand for the trial court to determine the appropriate relief.
FACTS
As provided by Â§ 6-1-320(A),[1] in most years, a municipality may raise its general operating (GO) millage rate above that of the year before only by the amount the consumer price index rose the preceding year.Â  In a year when a reassessment program[2] is implemented, however, the â€œrollback millage,â€ rather than the previous yearâ€™s millage, is the base GO millage rate.Â  Rollback
 millage is calculated under Â§ 12-37-251(E).[3]
Following a countywide reassessment in 1998, Myrtle Beach was required to use rollback millage calculated under Â§ 12-37-251(E) in setting its 1999-2000 GO millage rate.Â  Section 12-37-351(E) requires that the total assessed value of property, which is the divisor used in calculating the rollback millage, be adjusted by deducting the amount of the increase attributable to (1) new construction, (2) renovations to existing structures, and (3) property and improvements not previously taxed.Â  In calculating its rollback millage for 1999-2000, Myrtle Beach applied an additional variable to further reduce property values; it denominated this variable the â€œappeals allowance.â€Â  This variable took into account the fact that some owners would successfully appeal the new valuations placed on their properties.Â  Myrtle Beach used an appeals allowance of 7.5%.
In addition, Myrtle Beach adjusted the dividend used in calculating the rollback millage.Â  This dividend is the prior yearâ€™s property tax revenues.Â  Although Â§ 12-37-251(E) does not provide for any adjustment of this figure, Myrtle Beach applied an estimated collection rate of 86% to account for the fact that not all taxes billed would be collected.Â  It is undisputed that in making these adjustments to the rollback millage calculation specified by
Â§ 12-37-251(E), Myrtle Beach did not utilize the provisions of Â§ 6-1-320(C)[4] which allows the millage rate limitation to be overridden and the millage rate increased by a positive majority vote of the governing body at a special public meeting.Â 
ISSUE

Did the trial court err in determining that Myrtle Beachâ€™s method of calculating rollback millage was proper?

DISCUSSION
Angus contends that the circuit court erred in holding Myrtle Beach did not violate Â§ 12-37-251(E) by adding two variables to the statutory formula for calculating rollback millage without holding a public hearing as required by Â§ 6-1-320(C).Â  We agree that Â§ 12-37-251(E) and Â§ 6-1-320(A) do not permit Myrtle Beach to make these adjustments unless it utilizes the provisions of Â§ 6-1-320(C).
As noted above, Â§ 12-37-251(E) permits the use of three adjustments in calculating the rollback millage.Â  Angus argues, and we agree, that application of the statutory maxim inclusio unius est exclusio alterius mandates that these variables and no others be used in calculating the rollback millage.Â  The circuit court found this maxim inapplicable, reasoning that the variables used by Myrtle Beach â€œappear to be sensible and necessary devicesâ€ and that denying their use â€œwould lead to a result that is unworkable, inefficient, inaccurate, and problematic.â€Â  The variables permitted by the statute are clear and unambiguous; regardless of the merit of Myrtle Beachâ€™s formula, it is not what the statute allows.Â  See Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79, 533 S.E.2d 578 (2000) (where statutory language is clear and unambiguous, enumeration of certain exceptions excludes others).Â  
The fixing of a tax rate is a legislative function that must be given the greatest respect by the courts unless that function is exercised in an illegal manner.Â  Simkins v. City of Spartanburg, 269 S.C. 243, 237 S.E.2d 69 (1977).[5]Â  It is basic hornbook law that when a government entity levies a tax, â€œthe method outlined in the applicable law must be followed, at least in substance and especially concerning all mandatory provisions.â€Â  16 McQuillin Mun. Corp. Â§ 44.97 (3d ed. 1998).Â  We conclude Myrtle Beachâ€™s use of non-statutory variables violates Â§ 12-37-251(E).Â  Further, Myrtle Beach failed to hold a public meeting as provided under Â§ 6-1-320(C) which would have allowed it to legally override the mandatory requirements of subsection (A).
CONCLUSION
We hold the trial court erred in upholding Myrtle Beachâ€™s use of non-statutory variables to calculate rollback millage without the override vote required under Â§ 6-1-320(C) and we remand for the trial court to determine the appropriate relief.Â  We affirm Myrtle Beachâ€™s appeal pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR.Â  See Waller v. Seabrook Island Prop. Owners Assâ€™n, 300 S.C. 465, 388 S.E.2d 799 (1990) (decision to certify a class rests in trial judgeâ€™s discretion); Charleston County Parents for Public Schools, Inc. v. Moseley, 343 S.C. 509, 541 S.E.2d 543 (2001) (party that is not indispensable need not be joined under Rule 19, SCRCP).
AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART; AND REMANDED.Â Â  
 TOAL, C.J., and Acting Justice Deadra L. Jefferson, concur.Â  PLEICONES, J., dissenting in a separate opinion in which BURNETT, J., concurs.
JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  I agree that Myrtle Beach erred in relying upon non-statutory factors in computing the GO rollback millage.Â  I would find, however, that Angus has shown no prejudice and would therefore affirm the circuit courtâ€™s order denying her relief. 
At the time Myrtle Beach was calculating its 1999-2000 GO millage rate in June 1999, it was required to estimate the prior yearâ€™s property tax revenues since final figures are not provided to it by the county auditor until August.Â  The city estimated its prior yearâ€™s revenue by applying an 86% â€œcollection rateâ€ to the overall amount billed.Â  Further, while Myrtle Beach had available the new assessment values, the appeals process whereby property owners may seek a reduction in valuation was not yet complete.
The use of non-statutory variables violated S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-31-251(E) (2000).Â  The reality of municipal budgeting is that it is an inexact science, relying as it must upon estimates and â€œbest guesses.â€Â  As this Court recognized in Simkins v. City of Spartanburg, 269 S.C. 243, 237 S.E.2d 69 (1977), municipalities must rely upon imperfect and incomplete calendar year figures to meet their obligation to enact a fiscal year budget.Â  Simkins held that a city â€œcan proceed on the basis of past experience and the best available estimate of revenueâ€¦.â€Â  Id. at 249, 237 S.E.2d at 72; see also County of Lee v. Stevens, 277 S.C. 421, 289 S.E.2d 155 (1982) (â€œIt is a fact of life not all property taxes are ever collectedâ€). 
Although Myrtle Beach erred in relying on the nonstatutory variables, Angus has not shown prejudice.Â  First, she does not challenge the circuit courtâ€™s finding that Myrtle Beach could lawfully have levied a total of 65 mills in 1999-2000, but levied only 61.Â  Further, Angus does not challenge the circuit courtâ€™s calculation showing that Myrtle Beachâ€™s GO millage for 1999-2000 exceeded that permitted by Â§ 12-37-251(E) by approximately 4.44 mills.Â  When the city learned it had overcollected taxes for 1999-2000, it reduced the following yearâ€™s millage by 2.3 mills.Â  As the Court said in Lee County, â€œIf in the last analysis during some particular year there is a modest surplus or a modest deficit, no serious harm will come.Â  Adjustments can be made the ensuing year.â€Â  Id. at 427, 289 S.E.2d at 158.Â  Myrtle Beach made such an adjustment.
I would hold that while Myrtle Beach erred in calculating the GO rollback millage, this error was within the latitude afforded taxing entities that must rely on incomplete figures when calculating millage rates. [6]Â  Simkins, supra; Lee County, supra.Â  Further, I recognize that in calculating this rollback millage, Myrtle Beach relied upon the advice provided by the Department of Revenue to all municipalities located in counties that had undergone a reassessment.[7]Â  The effect of the majorityâ€™s decision today is to subject these municipalities to refund litigation over relatively nominal sums.Â  Such a result is not required by our precedents, and imposes an unnecessary fiscal burden on our cities and their current taxpayers.Â  I would affirm the order of the circuit court. 
BURNETT, J., concurs.

[1]Section 6-1-320(A) provides:

Notwithstanding Section 12-37-251(E), a local governing body may increase the millage rate imposed for general operating purposes above the rate imposed for such purposes for the preceding tax year only to the extent of the increase in the consumer price index for the preceding calendar year.Â  However, in the year in which a reassessment program is implemented, the rollback millage, as calculated pursuant to Section 12-37-251(E), must be used in lieu of the previous yearâ€™s millage rate. 

[2]Countywide reassessments and equalizations of real property are conducted every fifth year.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§12-43-217 (2000).Â  Municipalities and other taxing entities within a county use the countyâ€™s property valuations.
[3]Section 12-37-251(E) provides:

Rollback millage is calculated by dividing the prior year property tax revenues by the adjusted total assessed value applicable in the year the values derived from a countywide equalization and reassessment program are implemented.Â  This amount of assessed value must be adjusted by deducting assessments added for property or improvements not previously taxed, for new construction, and for renovation of existing structures. 

[4]Section 6-1-320(C) provides:

The millage rate limitation provided for in subsection (A) of this section may be overridden and the millage rate may be further increased by a positive majority vote of the appropriate governing body.Â  The vote must be taken at a specially-called meeting held solely for the purpose of taking a vote to increase the millage rate.Â  The governing body must provide public notice of the meeting notifying the public that the governing body is meeting to vote to override the limitation and increase the millage rate.Â  Public comment must be received by the governing body prior to the override vote.

[5] Despite our recognition of this basis principle in Simkins, we excused an illegal tax rate in County of Lee v. Stevens, 277 S.C. 421, 289 S.E.2d 155 (1982).Â  In that case, a county auditor challenged the countyâ€™s authority to set the tax rate before current property values were known.Â  We held the modest deficit caused by the countyâ€™s error could be excused, but we prospectively ordered the tax rate to be based upon current property valuations.Â  We found a prospective ruling necessary as a matter of â€œpracticability and reasonablenessâ€ because of the various methods in use at the time by local governments statewide.
We view County of Lee v. Stevens as a narrow exception and decline to follow it here.Â  The critical factor in that case was that there was no standard procedure in place to accomplish the statutory requirement at the local level; to strictly enforce that requirement would have caused havoc for local governments statewide.Â  Here, there is no such special circumstance.Â  We cannot condone a taxing entityâ€™s illegal acts in fixing the tax rate simply because the resulting impact may be characterized as modest.Â  
[6] A taxpayer, whose property tax bill was too high because a city or county made a minor error in calculating the millage rate in reliance upon advice from the Department of Revenue, is in a different position from a taxpayer who has been required to pay a disproportionate share of property taxes as the result of the taxing entityâ€™s adoption of a patently unlawful ordinance.Â  Thus, Angus and others affected by Myrtle Beachâ€™s good faith efforts to set the appropriate millage are not in the same position as Charleston County taxpayers who were unlawfully taxed pursuant to an ordinance capping valuation increases for owner-occupied residences at 15% while placing no cap on non-owner occupied property.Â  These taxpayers were entitled to a refund.Â  See Riverwoods, LLC v. County of Charleston, 349 S.C. 378, 563 S.E.2d 651 (2002).Â  The difference between the taxing decision made by Myrtle Beach and that made by Charleston County is more than a matter of degree: Charleston created two classes of taxpayers, in order to lighten the tax burden on one group by shifting it to the other.Â  Further, the impact of the Charleston Ordinance on owners of non-capped property could not be characterized as â€œmodest.â€
